basics.name: Scott Willis
basics.label: Specialist in Materials Science, Programming and British Humour

highlights: Developed applications with GUIs in Python & LabVIEW for collecting & cleaning measurement data from instruments for data visualisation.
Computer vision projects for detecting objects and patterns for QR codes.
NLP projects for extracting data from experiment reports using regex.
VBA scripts for macro-enabled laboratory books that extract & upload data between Word & Excel files to maintain ISO9000 quality standards.
Completed LabVIEW Core 1 training program with NI to work on data collection of failed electronic devices (ASICs, PCBs, MEMS, Batteries).
Developed a Python executable for assembling test data for over 5000 devices and uploading the results into an SQL database with pyodbc.
Scatterplot matrix analysis over the newly acquired data set of failed sensor devices with seaborn & pandas identified fingerprint patterns of failure.

Using these fingerprint characteristics for sorting newly incoming devices, the number of failure analysis cases closed each month by the department increased from 20 to 150 cases within one month of their identification.

references.name: Simon M. Humphrey, MChem, Ph. D.
references.reference:
It is my pleasure to support Scott, and I recommend him to you without reservation. I have known Scott for approximately 2 years. He worked in my research labs in Austin, Texas, as a visiting scholar, via an international exchange program. Scott took my graduate-level classes during his time in Austin, and also performed for-credit research studies alongside one of my current Ph.D. students during the 2018/19 academic year. Please also note that before taking a faculty position in Austin, I was on the faculty at the University of Cambridge and held a teaching fellowship there.
      I first met Scott in my role as adviser for incoming overseas exchange students in our department. Scott immediately struck me as a highly motivated, serious and mature student. Scott took all the extracurricular opportunities available to him at U.T. Austin, including working in two research labs, including my own. In my lab, Scott learned how to synthesize and characterize noble metal nanoparticle catalyst materials, prepared using non-conventional methods, including microwave-assisted synthesis. Throughout his time in my group, I interacted with him extensively, including in group meetings. He is an excellent communicator and works very well with others. He was meticulous in his laboratory work, and worked very safely. Scott also displayed perseverance in the manufacture of the mesoporous and amorphous catalyst support materials. He quickly adapted well to new areas of research and showed the hallmarks of an excellent researcher with extensive capability. I would assert that Scott is technically minded, so he was adept at working with specialist equipment such as microwave reaction chambers and catalyst line trials, grasping new analytical techniques quickly. In my labs, he learned a few characterization skills in a truly hands-on sense, including powder X-ray diffraction and inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy.
      Scott was collaborative in his research efforts. He is clearly a determined and ambitious individual with the drive and enthusiasm to move into the field of health data science. Scott is a strong team player as well as a future leader. He was always receptive to new ideas and improvements for the project. Scott also spent time reviewing contemporary literature and showed a genuine interest in recent advances in our field
      of research. I would happily welcome Scott back into my own lab as a graduate student, or would recommend him to any of my colleagues. From my first-hand observations, I can say with certainty that Scott will thrive in any research environment.
      I have no reservations in recommending Scott; I would say he is comparable to the top 5% of undergraduate students graduating from UT
